prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
WIBTA, for leaving my fiance of 7 years.
My fiance and I have been together for 7 years now and have an almost 6 year old son together.

Almost 3 years ago now we had broken up for about a month. During this time he began to talk to a girl that he's known for most of his life. We got back together, and I expected him to break off all contact with her. Which I thought was understandable.

2 weeks in and he still has her on all social media including snapchat. We fought and fought over it and he eventually deleted her. Or so I thought.

Last October, we had been growing rather distant and I took it upon myself to snoop through his phone.

And there she is. She had blocked me on social media so that I couldn't see them following each other. He had literally liked every single one of her pictures, not any of mine during the same time period to be clear, and she liked his as well. Including a picture of his Snapchat code asking people to add him.

I confront him. He becomes angry and defensive but swears hell get rid of her.

About a month later I decide to check again. And she's still there. So I told him I was leaving him.

He left for about 3 days. And we eventually talked things through and he again swore to delete her and block her for good.

3 weeks ago, I saw that he had liked pictures of the girl's sister on Instagram. He says he had remembered liking them from a long time ago and had been trying to unlike them so I would never find them and in doing so accidentally re liked the pictures, and I believed him.

Last night. He has both the girl AND her sister unblocked AGAIN on social media. Meaning he went out of his way to go through his settings, get to privacy, open his list of blocked users and unblocked those two in particular.

WIBTA for ending a 7 year relationship with the father of my son because he can't seem to let go of some other girl? Even though the only thing I really have evidence of is them staying in contact, not actually cheating?

I'm at a complete loss.
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's try to figure out whether the author is in the wrong here. So the situation is about a seven-year engagement where the author is considering leaving their fiancé because of ongoing issues with him maintaining contact with a girl he's known for a long time. 

First, the main points from the scenario: They broke up for a month three years ago, and during that time, the fiancé started talking to this girl. After getting back together, the author expected him to cut off contact, which he initially did. But later, the author found out he was still in contact through social media, liking her posts, etc. The author snooped and found this, leading to confrontations. The fiancé promised to delete her each time, but it kept happening again. The latest incident is that he unblocked both her and her sister, which the author found out and decided to leave.

Now, the question is whether the author is in the wrong. The user wants a yes or no answer based on whether the author is in the wrong. 

Let me break it down. The key factors here are the fiancé's actions and the author's response. The author has evidence that the fiancé hasn't followed through on promises to cut contact with another woman, even after multiple confrontations. The fiancé might be emotionally involved or at least maintaining inappropriate contact, which can be a deal-breaker in a relationship. The author has a child with him, so the stability of their relationship is important for the child's well-being.

On the other hand, the fiancé claims that some of the likes were accidental, like the sister's posts. But the author has observed a pattern over time, where despite assurances, the contact persists. The author's decision to leave is based on trust issues and the other person's inability to respect the author's boundaries. 

In relationships, trust is crucial. If one partner repeatedly breaches the other's trust, even without physical cheating, it can be grounds for ending the relationship. The author isn't accusing of cheating but of maintaining emotional ties that cause pain and distrust. Since the author has a right to expect exclusivity and respect in the relationship, and the fiancé hasn't been able to meet those expectations despite multiple chances, the author's decision to leave seems justified. 

So, considering all that, the author isn't in the wrong. The answer would be B.
